#Text=2.2 The Motivated Learner
#Text=Questions to consider :
#Text=How do different types of motivation affect my learning ?
#Text=What is resilience and grit ?
#Text=How can I apply the Uses and Gratification Theory to make decisions about my learning ?
#Text=How do I prevent negative bias from hindering learning ?
#Text=In this section , you will continue to increase your ability as an informed learner .
#Text=Here you will explore how much of an influence motivation has on learning , as well as how to use motivation to purposefully take an active role in any learning activity .

#Text=Rather than passively attempting to absorb new information , you will learn how to make conscious decisions about the methods of learning you will use ( based on what you intend to do with the information ) , how you will select and use learning materials that are appropriate for your needs , and how persistent you will be in the learning activity .
#Text=There are three main motivation concepts that have been found to directly relate to learning .
#Text=Each of these has been proven to mean the difference between success and failure .

#Text=You will find that each of these is a strong tool that will enable you to engage with learning material in a way that not only suits your needs , but also gives you ownership over your own learning processes .
#Text=Resilience and Grit
#Text=While much of this chapter will cover very specific aspects about the act of learning , in this section , we will present different information that may at first seem unrelated .
#Text=Some people would consider it more of a personal outlook than a learning practice , and yet it has a significant influence on the ability to learn .
#Text=What we are talking about here is called grit or resilience .
#Text=Grit can be defined as personal perseverance toward a task or goal .
#Text=In learning , it can be thought of as a trait that drives a person to keep trying until they succeed .
#Text=It is not tied to talent or ability , but is simply a tendency to not give up until something is finished or accomplished .
#Text=Figure 2.3
#Text=U.S. Army veteran and captain of the U.S. Invictus team , Will Reynolds , races to the finish line .
#Text=( Credit : DoD News / Flickr / Attribution 2.0 Generic ( CC-BY 2.0 ) )
#Text=The study showed that grit and perseverance were better predictors of academic success and achievement than talent or IQ .
#Text=This personality trait was defined as “ grit ” by the psychologist Angela Duckworth . 1
#Text=In a 2007 study Duckworth and colleagues found that individuals with high grit were able to maintain motivation in learning tasks despite failures .

#Text=The study examined a cross section of learning environments , such as GPA scores in Ivy League universities , dropout rates at West Point , rankings in the National Spelling Bee , and general educational attainment for adults .
#Text=What the results showed was that grit and perseverance were better predictors of academic success and achievement than talent or IQ .
#Text=Duckworth , A. L. ; Peterson , C. ; Matthews , M. D. ; Kelly , D. R. ( June 2007 ) . " Grit : Perseverance and passion for long - term goals " .
#Text=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology . 92 ( 6 ) : 1087 – 1101 . doi:10.1037/0022-3514.92.6.1087 . PMID 17547490 .
#Text=Applying Grit
#Text=The concept of grit is an easy one to dismiss as something taken for granted .

#Text=In our culture , we have a number of sayings and aphorisms that capture the essence of grit : “ If at first you do not succeed , try , try again , ” or the famous quote by Thomas Edison : “ Genius is one percent inspiration , ninety - nine percent perspiration . ”
#Text=The problem is we all understand the concept , but actually applying it takes work .
#Text=If the task we are trying to complete is a difficult one , it can take a lot of work .
#Text=The first step in applying grit is to adopt an attitude that looks directly to the end goal as the only acceptable outcome .
#Text=With this attitude comes an acceptance that you may not succeed on the first attempt — or the nineteenth attempt .
#Text=Failed attempts are viewed as merely part of the process and seen as a very useful way to gain knowledge that moves you toward success .
#Text=An example of this would be studying for an exam .
#Text=In your first attempt at studying you simply reread the chapters of your textbook covered in the exam .
#Text=You find that while this reinforces some of the knowledge you have gained , it does not ensure you have all the information you will need to do well on the test .
#Text=You know that if you simply read the chapters yet again , there is no guarantee you are going to be any more successful .
#Text=You determine that you need to find a different approach .
#Text=In other words , your first attempt was not a complete failure , but it did not achieve the end goal , so you try again with a different method .
#Text=On your second try , you copy down all of the main points onto a piece of paper using the section headlines from the chapters .
#Text=After a short break you come back to your list and write down a summary of what you know about each item on your list .

#Text=This accomplishes two things : first , you are able to immediately spot areas where you need to learn more , and second , you can check your summaries against the text to make certain what you know is correct and adequate .
#Text=In this example , while you may not have yet achieved complete success , you will have learned what you need to do next .
#Text=In true grit fashion , for your next try , you study those items on your list where you found you needed a bit more information , and then you go through your list again .
#Text=This time you are able to write down summaries of all the important points , and you are confident you have the knowledge you need to do well on the exam .
#Text=After this , you still do not stop , but instead you change your approach to use other methods that keep what you have learned fresh in your mind .
